questions.text: A patient with history of coronary artery disease presents with pulse rate of 48/min and low BP. Patient has decreased myocardial contractility on Echo . Which of these anesthetic agents should be used for induction of anesthesia?
questions.solution: C Effects on the Cardiovascular System The hemodynamic stability seen with etomidate is caused by its lack of effect on the sympathetic nervous system and on the function of the baroreceptor. Etomidate has proven useful in patients with valvular or ischemic heart disease who are undergoing noncardiac surgical procedures and in patients with poor cardiac function. The myocardial oxygen supply-to-demand ratio is well maintained. Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia 8th edition chapter 30 page 852

questions.text: Which of the following combinations can be used for day care surgery
questions.solution: A Definition of a day care case is “A surgical day case is a patient who is admitted for investigation or operation on a planned non-resident basis and who none the less requires facilities for recovery. The whole procedure should not require an overnight stay in a hospital bed.” Because the patient gets admitted , operated and discharged on the same day , therefore the basic idea of doing a case of day care surgery is to administer drugs with short duration of action, predictable effect, no respiratory depression or CNS depression and no or little nausea and vomiting. So for day care surgery general anesthesia is preferred over regional. Drugs used in day care surgery are: Premediation: oral \ iv midazolam Induction : intravenous > inhalational Intravenous agent: propofol Inhalational agent :sevoflurane>desflurane Opiods: remifentanil>alfentanil> fentanyl Neuromuscular blocking agents: rocuronium Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia 8th edition chapter 89 page 2625

questions.text: Muscle relaxant that can be used in patient with high S. Bilirubin of 6.0 and S.creatinine of 4.5 mg/dl
questions.solution: B Atracurium and cisatracurium are both metabolized by hofmann elimination which is spontaneous degradation at physiological temperature and ph and are independent of kidney or liver metabolism and therefore they both are safe to use in renal and \ or hepatic failure. Ref.: Miller's Anesthesia 8/e p976

questions.text: Which anesthetic agent can cause pain on IV administration
questions.solution: B Induction of anesthesia with propofol is associated with pain on injection apnea hypotension thrombophlebitis of the vein into which propofol is injected. Pain on injection is reduced by using a large vein avoiding veins in the dorsum of the hand adding lidocaine to the propofol solution changing the propofol formulation( water soluble preparation called as fospropofol). Drugs in anethesia that cause pain on iv injection are: Propofol Etomidate Rocuronium Lorazepam and diazepam ( only oil formulations are available) Of these etomidate causes maximum pain on injection Ref.: Miller's Anesthesia 8/e p831

choices.text: general anesthesia with IV induction by ketamine
Spinal anesthesia up to L4 level
General anesthesia with IV induction by propofol followed by maintenance with fluranes

questions.text: a pregnant woman with placenta Previa started to bleed as she went into labor .Her blood pressure was 80/50 mm Hg. A lower segment cesarean section was planned in view of acute shock. What type of anesthesia will you plan for this patient?
questions.solution: A. general anesthesia with IV induction by ketamine Active bleeding or an unstable patient requires immediate cesarean section under general anesthesia. Ketamine causes sympathetic stimulation and thus is the agent of choice in acute shock. Propofol causes hypotension as a side effect and therefore has to be avoided in shock. Spinal anesthesia causes sudden and intense fall in blood pressure due to sympathetic ablation below the level of block and thus contraindicated in shock Epidural anesthesia causes less intense hypotension but activating the epidural takes time because of slower onset of action and thus can’t be used in acute shock. Ref: Morgan & Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 5th edition page 862

questions.text: The diagram of a correctly positioned proseal – type Laryngeal Mask Airway is provided below. Above What site is the arrow marked area of the airway positioned?
questions.solution: D Above esophagus Proseal laryngeal mask airway (PLMA): 2nd generation LMA Has a separate gastric drain tube In the PLMA, the drain tube opening at the distal tip of themask ensures that if the tip is not correctly placed againstthe UES, inflation of the reservoir bag causes some of thegas to be diverted back up the drain tube, providingmeasurable evidence of inadequate device placement. Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia 8th edition chapter 55 page 1666

questions.text: For what purpose is the instrument given below used for?
questions.solution: B. Lumbar puncture The picture shown is of a spinal needle Used to perform lumbar puncture for diagnostic tap of csf for identification and analysis of csf abnormalities or for administering local anesthetic for the purpose of providing anesthesia Ref: Harrison’s principles of Internal Medicine 18/e p 46

questions.text: While performing a lumbar puncture. A snap is felt just before entering into the epidural space. This is due to piercing entering into the epidural space. This is due to piercing of which structure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ligamentumflavam Technique Technique should be classified into a series of steps (i.e., the four Ps): preparation, position, projection, andpuncture. Preparation: Informed consent All equipments checked and ready Needle (dura splitting > dura cutting) Painting and draping of the parts Position: Sitting (most common) Lateral decubitus Prone(jack knife position) Projection: Spinal cord ends at L1-L2 so lumbar puncture should be done below this level Tuffier’sline( line joining both iliac crests) corresponds to L4 vertebral body or space between L4-L5. Puncture: Structures pierced are skin, subcutaneous tissue, and supraspinous ligament to reach the substance of the interspinous ligament. The needle, with its bevel parallel to the midline, is advanced slowly to heighten the sense of tissue planes traversed and to prevent skewing of nerve roots, until the characteristic change in resistance is noted as the needle passes through the ligamentumflavum and dura. On passing through the dura, there is often a slight “click” or “pop” sensation. The stylet is then removed, and CSF should appear at the needle hub. Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia 8th edition chapter 56 page 1700

questions.text: Identify the use of the following instrument:
questions.solution: a. Laryngoscopy The instrument shown in the picture is a LARYNGOSCOPE It is used to perform direct laryngoscopy followed by intubation of tracheal with an endotracheal tube. The Macintosh and Miller blades are the most popular curved and straight designs. Ref: Morgan & Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 5th edition page 332

questions.text: Which of these is the most reliable method for monitoring fluid resuscitation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Urine output In an adult, a child, and a newborn under 1 year old, an adequate urine output is 0.5 mL/kg per hour, 1 mL/kg per hour, and 2 mL/kg per hour, respectively.

questions.text: What are the minimum and maximum possible values of Glasgow Coma Score?
questions.solution: a. Minimum = 3, Maximum = 15 Ref: Harrison’s principles of Internal Medicine 18/e p 3381

questions.text: A patients was in surgery when suddenly the resident noticed the following plot on the capnograph monitor. What should be the immediate next step in management of the patients?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Increase muscle relaxant This capnography represents “curare notch” i.e spontaneous breathing efforts in phase III of the capnogram. At this point muscle relaxant has to be administered to deepen the level of relaxation. Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia 8th edition chapter 51 page 1554

questions.text: Which of these is the most commonly used as preanesthetic medication
questions.solution: d. Glycopyrrolate Pre anesthetic medication: this involves administration of drugs before the beginning to anesthesia to achieve desired goals. Goals of pre anesthetic medication are: Allay of anxiety To achieve amnesia of periop events. Prevention of secretions Analgesia To decrease the dose of anesthetic agents used To prevent vasovagal response to anesthesia Prevent the aspiration of gastric contents To prevent post operative nausea and vomiting To prevent anaphylactic / anaphyactoid reactions Different drugs are used to achieve the goals of premedication. For sedation, anti anxiety and amnesia : benzodiazepines are drug of choice. Best agent is midazolam For anti sialogougueeffect : anticholinergics are doc . in that glycopyrollate is best ( quaternary ammonium compound so no central effects) For post operative nausea and vomiting : 5HT3 receptor antagonists are drug of choice : ondansetron is the best. Ref: Morgan & Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 5th edition page 301

questions.text: What is the most reliable site to measure core temperature during general anesthesia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pulmonary Artery Each monitoring site has advantages and disadvantages. • The tympanic membrane theoretically reflects brain temperature because the auditorycanal’s blood supply is the external carotid artery. • Trauma during insertion and cerumen insulationdetract from the routine use of tympanic probes. • Rectal temperatures have a slow response to changesin core temperature. • Nasopharyngeal probes areprone to cause epistaxis, but accurately measure coretemperature if placed adjacent to the nasopharyngeal mucosa. • The thermistor on a pulmonary artery catheter also measures core temperature. • Liquid crystal adhesive strips placed on the skin areinadequate indicators of core body temperature duringsurgery. • Esophageal temperature sensors, often incorporated into esophageal stethoscopes, providethe best combination of economy, performance, and safety. • To avoid measuring the temperature of trachealgases, the temperature sensor should be positionedbehind the heart in the lower third of the esophagus. • Ref: Morgan & Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 5th edition page 137

choices.text: Grey body with black and white shoulder

questions.text: What is color of medical oxygen cylinder ?
questions.solution: c. Black body with white shoulder

questions.text: Asevofluranevapourizer can accurately deliver the dose of an anesthetic agent which resemble it in what of the following property:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Vapor pressure A vaporizer (anesthetic agent or vapor delivery device) is a device that changes a liquid anesthetic agent into its vapor and adds a controlled amount of that vapor to the fresh gas flow or the breathing system. Vapor pressure is defined as the pressure exerted by the vapors of the volatile liquid on the walls of the closed container it is kept in at a particular temperature. This property of the volatile liquid agent is dependent only on the agent and the ambient temperature and therefore vaporizers are vapor pressure specific. Agents with same vapor pressure will generate same amount of vapors in a closed containers and thus will deliver same output. Ref: dorsch and dorsch : understanding anesthesia equipments 5th edition chapter 6

choices.text: Inducing agentand neuro muscular relaxantare administered together
The patient is pre-oxygenated for 3 minutes before the procedure
Induction should be done with thiopentone sodium and succinylcholine for muscle relaxation
Cricoid pressure has to be applied till the endotracheal tube has been secured with a cuff

questions.text: All are true about rapid sequence induction done in a cardiac patient in emergency except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Induction should be done with thiopentone sodium and succinylcholine for muscle relaxation. RAPID SEQUENCE INDUCTION( RSI) The primary objective of RSI is to minimize the time interval between loss of consciousness and tracheal intubation. The essential features of RSI include preoxygenation with 100% oxygen, administration of a predetermined induction dose (usuallythiopentone 200 mg and succinylcholine 100 mg), application of effective Cricoid Pressure, and avoidance of positive-pressure ventilation until the airway is secured with a cuffed tracheal tube. Modified RSI: In certain clinical situations some aspects of original RSI can be modified depending the type of patient. Induction agent and dose can be changed Positive ventilation can be given keeping the pressure below 20cms of water. Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia 8th edition chapter 55 page 1656

choices.text: Block of cardio accelerator fibers of sympathetic origin

questions.text: A 46- year old male patient was given subarachnoid block by bupivacaine heavy by the anesthetist . after 10 minutes he was found to have a BP of 72/44 mm Hg and heart rate of 52/min. On checking the level of block it was found to be T6. What isthe likely explanation for the bradycardia :
questions.solution: C Bezoldjarish reflex Bezold-Jarisch Reflex The Bezold-Jarisch reflex responds to noxious ventricular stimuli sensed by chemoreceptors and mechanoreceptors within the left ventricular wall by inducing the triad of hypotension, bradycardia, and coronary artery dilatation. The activated receptors communicate along unmyelinated vagal afferent type C fibers. These fibers reflexively increase parasympathetic tone. Because it invokes bradycardia, the Bezold-Jarisch reflexis thought of as a cardioprotective reflex. This reflex has been implicated in the physiologic response to a range of cardiovascular conditions such as myocardial ischemia or infarction, thrombolysis, or revascularization and syncope. It has also been proposed as a mechanism of sudden severe bradycardia in a post spinal anesthesia patient when the level of blockade is below T4. About other options The Bainbridge reflex is elicited by stretch receptorslocated in the right atrial wall and the cavoatrial junction. An increase in right-sided filling pressure(increase in venous return) sends vagal afferent signals to the cardiovascular center in the medulla. These afferent signals inhibit parasympathetic activity, thereby increasing the heart rate. Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia 8th edition chapter 20 page 490

questions.text: Correct sequence of Age and MAC required is :
questions.solution: B Infants> neonates > adult The expired minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) of an inhaled anesthetic required in children changes withage. Anesthetic requirement is smaller for preterm than for term neonates and smaller for term neonates than for 3 month olds. Infants have a higher MAC than that of older children or adults Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia 8th edition chapter 93 page 2764

questions.text: Allergyin immediate perioperative periodis due to :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Neuromuscular blocker The most common causes of anaphylaxis in patients who experienced allergic reactions were reported to be NMBDs (58.2%), latex (16.7%), and antibiotics (15.1%). Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia 8th edition chapter 93 page 980

choices.text: Entry into the right sided bronchus

questions.text: A 40-year-old chronic smoker was scheduled for cholecystectomy under general anesthesia. He was induced with propofol and vecuronium and started on isoflurane for maintenance of anesthesia. During the procedure, the following capnograph plot was observed. What is the possible cause?
questions.solution: B. entry into the right sided bronchus This bifid waveform represents the differential ventilation of two lungs. basically, as the ETT is positioned mainly in the right main bronchus, the airflow through the right lung is the best, and right-sided gas forms the first (brisk and steep) part of the waveform. Afterwards, one notices that there is a secondary transitional phase, which is the gas from the left lung escaping slowly up into the ETT. Of course, if the left lung was completely isolated (i.e. you have the cuff inflated in such a way as to block it totally) you would not see this waveform. Ref: https://www.derangedphysiology.com/main/core-topics-intensive-care/mechanical-ventilation-0/Chapter%205.1.7/abnormal-capnography-waveforms-and-their-interpretation

choices.text: A slight pressure may be applied at the thyroid cartilage
The laryngoscope is held in the right hand introduced from the right side of the patient
The neck is flexed with extension at the atlanto-occipital joint
After insertion of laryngoscope, it is levered on the upper incisor to pull up the tongue and visualize the vocal cords

questions.text: During laryngoscopy and intubation procedure, all of these are true, except:
questions.solution: b. The laryngoscope is held in the right hand introduced from the right side of the patient We will discuss all options one by one Option A: This also called as BURP maneuver where in a Backward Upward Rightward Pressure is applied at the thyroid cartilage to improve the laryngeal view. Option C: The optimal position for laryngoscopy is called a “sniffing the morning air position” where there is flexion at the neck and extension at the atlanto occipital joint. Positioning the patient in the sniffing position approximates the alignment of oral, pharengeal and laryngeal axis. Cervical flexion aligns the pharyngeal and laryngeal axes, and maximal head extension at the atlantooccipital joint brings the oral axis closer into alignment Option D: The technique of laryngoscopy involves insertion of the blade of the scope from the right side of the mouth and sweeping the tongue on left side and placing the top of the blade just at the base of epiglottis and then lifting the epiglottis at an angle of 45 degree and at the same time levering the handle on the upper incisors. Option B: The laryngoscope handle is to be held in the left hand, and the flange on the left side that is used to retract the tongue laterally and the epiglottis is lifted. Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia 8th edition chapter 55 page 1667

questions.text: What is the ratio of chest compressions and breaths when a lone person is giving cardiopulmonary resuscitation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) According to 2015 ACC-AHA guidelines for cardio pulmonary resuscitation the order in giving cpr is C>A>B. High-quality CPR includes: o Perform compressions at a rate between 100 and 120 per minute, regardless of the age of the victim o Chest compressions should be between 2 and 2.4 inches (5 to 6 cm) for adults and adolescents o Chest compressions should be given to a depth of 1/3 the diameter of the chest in infants and children up to puberty. This is about 1.5 inches (4 cm) in infants and 2 inches (5 cm) in children o Allow the chest to completely recoil between compressions so that the heart can completely refill o Do not interrupt compressions except to use an AED or change providers o Interruptions should be limited to no more than 10 seconds at a time o Chest compressions should make up at least 60% of the rescue time o Deliver each breath over 1 second, regardless of victim age o Prevent over-inflation of the lungs by avoiding rapid ventilations o Perform CPR as a team to perform activities more quickly and efficiently o When no advanced airway in place that the ratio of chest compression to ventilation is 30:2 o When an advanced airway is in place, ventilate at 1 breath every 6 seconds (10 breaths per minute). Ref: AHA 2015 CPR Guidelines

questions.text: Why 100% Oxygen is administered after nitrous oxide is discontinued on emergence from anesthesia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Diffusion hypoxia (FINK effect) Happens towards the end of anesthesia Elimination of nitrous oxide is so rapid that alveolar oxygen and CO2 are diluted. Alveolar hypoxia and alveolar hypocapnea cause decrease in ventilatory drive and eventually leading to arterial hypoxemia. The resulting diffusion hypoxia is prevented by administering 100% oxygen for 5–10 min after discontinuing nitrous oxide. Ref: Morgan & Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 5th edition page 159

questions.text: A surgeon decides to operate a patient under epidural anesthesia. 3% Xylocaine with adrenaline is used for administering epidural anesthesia. The patient suddenly develops hypotension after 3 minutes of administration. What is the likely cause for this?
questions.solution: d. Penetration into the subarachnoid space Complications Associated with Needle or Catheter Insertion Inadequate Anesthesia or Analgesia Movement of the needle during injection incomplete entry of the needle opening into the subarachnoid space, subdural injection loss of potency of the local anesthetic solution may be responsible B. Intravascular Injection Accidental intravascular injection of the local anesthetic for epidural and caudal anesthesia can produce very high serum levels. Extremely high levels of local anesthetics affect the central nervous system (seizure and unconsciousness) and the cardiovascular system (hypotension, arrhythmias, and depressed contractility). Because the dosage of medication for spinal anesthesia is relatively small, this complication is seen after epidural and caudal (but not spinal) blocks. The incidence of intravascular injection can be minimized by carefully aspirating the needle (or catheter) before every injection, using a test dose, always injecting local anesthetic in incremental doses, and close observation for early signs of intravascular injection (tinnitus, lingual sensations). Treatment is resuscitative, and lipid rescueshould be employed C. Total Spinal Anesthesia Total spinal anesthesia can occur followingattempted epidural/caudal anesthesia if there isaccidental intrathecal injection. Onset is usuallyrapid, because the amount of anestheticrequiredfor epidural and caudal anesthesia is 5–10 times thatrequired for spinal anesthesia. Careful aspiration,use of a test dose, and incremental injection techniquesduring epidural and caudal anesthesiacanhelp avoid this complication. D. Subdural Injection The spinal subdural space is a potential space between the dura and the arachnoid containing a small amount of serous fluid. This space extends intracranially, so that anesthetic injected into the spinal subdural space can ascend to higher levels than epidural medications Clinical presentationsimilar to that of high spinal anesthesia, withthe exception that the onset may be delayed for15–30 min and the block may be “patchy”. Ref: Morgan & Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 5th edition page 968

choices.text: The bevel should face upwards while inserting the needle
To be done in lateral recumbent position

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the procedure done with the needle shown below?
questions.solution: B Coagulation disorder is a relative contraindication to lumbar puncture Ref: (Millers anesthesia 8th edition pg 1691) Absolute contraindications: patient refusal, localized sepsis, and an allergy to any of the drugs planned for administration, A patient’s inability to maintain stillness during needle puncture, raised intracranial pressure, which may theoretically predispose to brainstem herniation. Option A: Breath holding is not a requirement for the procedure. Option C: The bevel should face upwards when the position of the patient is lateral and face right or left when the patient is sitting for the procedure. this is done to prevent the cutting of duralfibres and thus reducing the chance of PDPH Option D: Can be done in sitting , lateral or prone ( rarely done).

questions.text: Anaesthesia of choice for induction
questions.solution: C None of the options are true induction agents in strict sense. Bupivacaine is a local anesthetic and is not used for induction of anesthesia Neostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor and is used for reversal of NDMRs Dexmedetomidine is an Alpha agonist and is used as a sedative, anxiolytic, analgesic agent. It is used as an adjuvant to anesthetic drugs. Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine and is a highly potent drug with slow onset and prolonged dyration of action. Of all the options only benzodiazepines can be used as induction agent. Of these agents midazolam is the agent of the choice. Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia 8th edition chapter 30 page 842

questions.text: Highest o2 delivery by
questions.solution: B Ref: Benumof and Hagberg’s Airway Management, Chapter 14, page 304, 305, and 307

questions.text: Before endotracheal intubation, oxygenation given for how much time?
questions.solution: 3 mins Preoxygenation is typically performed via a facemask attached to either the anesthesia machine or a Mapleson circuit. To ensure adequate preoxygenation, 100% oxygen must be provided at a flow rate high enough to prevent rebreathing (10 to 12 L/min), and no leaks around the facemask must be present. An end-tidal concentration of oxygen greater than 90% is considered to maximize apnea time. Two primary methods are used to accomplish preoxygenation. The first method uses tidal volume ventilation through the facemask for 3 minutes, which allows the exchange of 95% of the gas in the lungs. The second method uses vital capacity breaths to achieve adequate preoxygenation more rapidly. Four breaths over 30 seconds is not as effective as the tidal volume method but may be acceptable in certain clinical situations; eight breaths over 60 seconds has been shown to be more effective. Head-up positioning has been shown to improve the quality of preoxygenation in both obese and nonobese patients. Ref: millers 8th edition page 1653

questions.text: Suction done for how many seconds?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 15 SECONDS OR LESS Tracheal secretions should only be suctioned for 10 to 15 seconds at most. The patient should be preoxygenated for at least a minute with 10% oxygen, and the total suction time should not exceed 10-15 seconds for each attempt.

choices.text: make patient sit and aspirate out secretions
put the tube back under sedation
give bag and mask and look for spontaneous respiratory efforts.
give chest physiotherapy to remove d secretions

questions.text: A patient on ventillation in ICU with ET tube. Suddenly his family member comes to you and says he has pulled out the tube. What will u do next ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Here the significance is on the fact that the patient pulled out the tube himself, that means either the patient is fully conscious and awake and therefore he has pulled the tube or that he is disoriented and partially awake...so after removal of the tube by such a patient, we will 1st hold a mask and look at the bag for adequacy of respiration. If efforts are adequate and patient is conscious then we won’t do anything else, but if he is not Breathing properly and can’t maintain airway then we need to reintubate the patient..

questions.text: Fibre least sensitive to local anaesthesia
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Order of sensitivity of fibres to local anesthetics A delta=A gamma > A beta=A alpha > B > C

choices.text: Equal use of crystalloids and colloids
Permissive hypotension and limited crystalloid use
Management of airway breathing and circulation

questions.text: Balanced resuscitation means?
questions.solution: B Balanced resuscitation, which includes permissive hypotension, limiting crystalloid use, and the transfusion of blood products in ratios similar to whole blood. Prompt initiation of massive transfusion and the protocolled use of 1:1:1 product ratios have improved the morbidity and mortality of patients with trauma in hemorrhagic shock. Balanced resuscitation minimizes the impact of trauma-induced coagulopathy, limits blood product waste, and reduces the complications that occur with aggressive crystalloid resuscitation. Permissive hypotension—also known as "hypotensive" or "balanced" resuscitation—is a strategy of deferring or restricting fluid administration until haemorrhage is controlled, while accepting a limited period of suboptimum end-organ perfusion. Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia 8th edition chapter 82 page 2467

questions.text: Patient being given analgesia for labor .What drug should be kept at hand ?
questions.solution: B NALOXONE , Most common method of providing labour analgesia is through an epidural. During the 2nd stage of labor ,opiods are used as a sole analgesic agents to relieve the pain as they donot cause motor blockade and thus patient can ambulate. Use of opiods like morphine and fentanyl can be associated with high chances of sudden respiratory depression Naloxone is a pure opiod antagonist PURE OPIOD ANTAGONIST, USED IN THE TREATMENT OF OPIOD INDUCED REPIRATORY DEPRESSION Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia 8th edition chapter 31 page 906

choices.text: Start CPR, give 2 rescue breath, assess pulse
Give rescue breath, se pulse, start CPR
Assess patient, activate emergency response team, and call for defibrillator, start CPR

questions.text: What is the sequence of events according to BLS
questions.solution: C

questions.text: A patient is undergoing MRND for laryngeal malignancy; while dissecting he venous tributaries the surgeon elevated the internal jugular vein for ligation. Suddenly the patients EtCO2 dropped from 38 mmhg to 12 mmhg and the patient developed hypotension along with cardiac arrhythmia. Which of the following is most likely cause?
questions.solution: C Venous air embolism Can occur in surgeries above the level of heart. Most cpommonly occurs in sitting position eg: posterior fossa surgery, shoulder surgery Most sensitive investigation is TTE > precordial doppler> end tidal N2> end tidal CO2>CBP> mill wheel murmur Immediate management is suction the central line.

questions.text: Identify the image
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) temperature probe

choices.text: Thermodilution method in Pulmonary artery catheter
Continuous Cardiac output monitoring via pulmonary artery

questions.text: Not used for measuring cardiac output inanICUpatient is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Techniques of cardiac output monitoring: Classified based on invasiveness: Invasive techniques: Pulmonary artery catheter ( thermodilution and continuous cardiac output measurement) Less invasive techniques: Transpulmonarythermodilution Ultrasound flow dilution Pulse contour and pulse pressure analysis Respiratory derived cardiac output monitoring system: partial CO 2-rebreathing Transesophageal echocardiography Esophageal Doppler Non-invasive techniques Transthoracic echocardiography Non-invasive pulse contour systems Bioimpedance Estimated continuous cardiac output Ultrasonic cardiac output monitoring

choices.text: Ventricular dysrhythmia are uncommon in children
Infant myocardium is more refractory to hypoxia due to congenital heart disease
More ventilation to be given compared to chest compression
Dissolved oxygen concentration is more in pre arrest state

questions.text: Correct regarding difference between adult n children resuscitation?
questions.solution: C Ventricular dysrhythmias are not a common cause of cardiac arrest in children. Hypoxia induced bradycardia are more important cause and that is why rescue breaths are more important in paediatric resuscitation The ratio of ventilation to compression in an infant is 3:1 and in children with 2 rescuers is 15:2.

questions.text: Anesthetic agent known to cause pain on intravenous injection:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Both etomidate and propofol cause pain on injection, but etomidate is more painful than propofol.

questions.text: Anesthectic agent with least minimum alveolar concentration (MAC):
questions.solution: B Minimum alveolar concentration or MAC is the concentration of a vapour in the alveoli of the lungs that is needed to prevent movement in 50% of subjects in response to surgical stimulus. MAC is used to compare the strengths, or potency, of anaesthetic vapours.

questions.text: Inhalational agent with lowest blood gas coefficient is:
questions.solution: C Xenon is an inert non irritant, non inflammable agent used in anesthesia. It acts by blocking NMDA channels. It has the lowest blood gas co-efficient leading to faster onset of anesthesia

choices.text: Aspirin should be stopped 7 days before surgery
Unfractionated heparin should be stopped 7 days before surgery
Fondaparinux should be stopped 7 days before surgery
Clopidrogrel should be stopped 7 days before surgery

questions.text: Regarding Neuraxial Anesthesia, which of the following statement is true?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Clopidogrel should be stopped 7 days before surgery. The minimum duration period for Discontinuation of drugs prior to a regional anaesthetic procedure : A)Aspirin : Try to continue - unless major chances of bleeding stops for 3 days. B) Clopidogrel : 7 days C) Ticagrelor : 5 to 7 days D) Prasugrel : 7 to 10 days E) Ticlopidine : 10 days F) Cangrelor : 3 hours G) Extended release Dipyridamole : 24 hours H) Abciximab : 24 to 48 hours I) Eptifibatide & Tirofiban : 4 to 8 hours

questions.text: A resident at the emergency department is preparing for a lumbar puncture in a 26 years old female with suspected subarachnoid bleeding. Although she presented with altered sensorium, CT brain was found to be normal. During LP, which structure is pierced after the spinal needle crosses interspinous ligament?
questions.solution: layers punctured during lumbar puncture are 1- Skin 2- Facia and SC fat 3- Surpaspinous ligament 3- Interspinous ligament 5- Ligamentumflavum 6- Epidural space and fat (epidural anesthesia needle stops here) 7- Dura

questions.text: Local anesthetic acts by:
questions.solution: A Local anesthetic drugs enter the neurons and ionise inside the cells . they cause blockage of Na+ channels leading to hyperpolarisation which reduces its excitability.

choices.text: Increase in saturation more than 90% in 2 mins

questions.text: All are signs of Esophageal intubation except.
questions.solution: A Esophageal intubation is a complication of tracheal intubation. In esophageal intubation, the ventilating air is passing through mediastinum hence thoracic sounds are heard. Declining capnogram is present . no chest movements as the air enters the stomach.

questions.text: Which of the following composition has the least probability to catch fire in ET tube, when used in laryngeal cancer surgery.?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Most dreaded complication during laser surgery is Airway fire To prevent airway fire : decrease FiO2 as low as u can, do not use Nitrous oxide, and use air.

choices.text: By breathing bag of anaesthesia circuit
By giving 15L/min O2 via nasal cannula

questions.text: High oxygen jet flush achieved by administration of which of the following through 14G iv catheter intratracheally
questions.solution: A It is a case of needle cricothyroidotomy. Indications are Upper airway obstruction: foreign body Laryngospasm Difficult intubation CICU ( cant intubate cant ventilate)

questions.text: Which anesthetic is contraindicated in chronic renal failure?
questions.solution: ABD Ref: Morgan 4th Ed/219 Explanation:Anesthetic agents contraindicated in renal failure Predmedication: Opioids Muscle relaxants: Gllamine, Pipecuranium, Pancuronium. IV induction agents: Ketamine, Thiopentone (relative CI) Inhalational agents: Methoxyflurane, Enflurane, Sevoflurane Sch, Desflurane and Propofol are safe

questions.text: In ophthalmic surgery, a patient is allergic to aminoesters. Which among the following can be used?
questions.solution: CD Ref: Lee’s 13th Ed/486, Morgan’s Anesthesia Explanation: Prilocaine and Bupivacaine are amides, not aminoesters. Hence they can be used safely

choices.text: Sevoflurane is the agent of choice for children and asthma patients
Sevoflurane should not be used where the gas flow rate is less than 2 L/min
Desflurane should not be used for induction in children
Isoflurane is more potent than sevoflurane
Halothane is the agent of choice for day care surgery over Sevoflurane

questions.text: TRUE statement(s) regarding inhalational anesthesia is/ are?
questions.solution: ABCD Explanation: For day care surgery, Desflurane and Sevoflurane are preferred over Halothane. Other options are correct.

questions.text: A patient due to be taken for LSCS, develops hypotension within 7-8 min of spinal anesthesia. Drug(s) useful in treating this patient may include?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B, D & E) Ref: Miller 7th Ed/1617 Explanation: Treatment of spinal anesthesia-induced hypotension Fluid loading Vasopressors Phenylephrine (DOC) Ephedrine Norepinephrine/Epinephrine infusion i.v. Dopamine and Mephenteramine have also been tried Atropine for bradycardia

choices.text: Prilocaine is longer acting then bupivacaine
Tetracaine is more potent than lignocaine
Dibucaine is the longest acting local anesthetic

questions.text: True regarding local anesthetics is/are?
questions.solution: BCD Ref: Ajay Yadav 4th Ed/118 Explanation: Option A is incorrect. Prilocaine is intermediate acting, whereas bupivacaine is long acting LA Option E is incorrect. Cocaine has sympathomimetic activity and thus causes hypertension. Other options are correct

choices.text: Cell counts like total differential counts

questions.text: Ifyou are asked to collect 4 serial samples from lumbar punctures, what should be done with the first sample?
questions.solution: A Explanation: After CSF collection, divide into 4 tubes Tube 1: Total cell count and differentials Tube 2: Glucose and protein Tube 3: Gram stain and culture Tube 4: Additional tests

questions.text: Which among the following anesthetic agent(s) is/are used in spinal anesthesia?
questions.solution: B, C Preservative free local anesthetics can be used in spinal anesthesia. Because the preservatives used will cause arachnoiditis. The most commonly used local anesthetic in spinal anesthesia is bupivacaine > lignocaine. The concentrations in which they can be used are : Bupivacaine: 0.5% and 0.75% Lignocaine: 1.5% and 5%

choices.text: CNS depression is an early feature

questions.text: True regarding LAST (local anesthetic systemic toxicity) is/are?
questions.solution: A, B, D LAST means local anesthetic entering systemic circulation and is present there above toxic concentration. Local anesthetics are sodium channel blockers and hence affect CNS and CVS. CNS symptoms appears first and then followed by CVS symptoms. • CNS symptoms are excitatory> depressive symptoms • CVS symptoms are of two types (a) Direct : when large doses of cardiotoxic drugs like bupivacaine affect transmission of neuronal impulses in myocardium. This leads to bradyarrythmia whch can cause cardiac arrest. Treatment for bupivacaine induced cadiotoxicity is intralipid which acts as reservoir of lipid in blood. This leads to increased dissociation of local anesthetic in heart. (b) Indirect: when higher level of blockade ( higher than T4) is given in spinal or epidural anesthesia, the cardio acceleratory fibres are blocked. This leads to profound hypotension and bradycardia.

questions.text: True regarding ketamine is/are?
questions.solution: A, C, D Ketamine is a phencyclidine derivative which causes dissociative anaesthesia. Effects of ketamine on various systems are CVS: increased heart rate and BP by indirect sympathomimetic activity. But it is a direct myocardial depressant. RS: bronchodilator CNS: increases ICT and increases cerebral metabolic rate of O2. Hence contraindicated in neurosurgery.

questions.text: All of the following condition(s) is/are associated with a difficult airway except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A, C, D AND E) • Choanal atresia : no problem with oral intubation • Fragile X syndrome : has high arched palate and prominent jaw. Associated with difficult airway. • Di George, pearson and turner’s syndrome have no difficult intubation. • The common congenital abnormalities leading to difficult airwar are: (a) Pierre robins syndrome (b) Trencher Collin syndrome (c) Goldenhar syndrome (d) Downs syndrome (e) Klippelfiel anomaly

choices.text: Epidural analgesia is contraindicated in HELLP patients
General anesthesia is always preferred in LSCS
Continuous ECG monitoring needed in obstetric anesthesia due to high risk of arrhythmias
General anesthesia needed in emergency LSCS
Anesthetics need dose modification in concomitant surgery in obstetric patients

questions.text: True regarding anesthesia in obstetric patient is/are?
questions.solution: A,C, D, E HELLP syndrome has low platelet count and epidural anesthesia is not done due to risk of epidural hematoma Anesthesia in LSCS : preffered method is regional block > General anesthesia Progesterone increses the sensitivity of nerves to anesthesia hence all anesthetic drugs needs to be given in reduced dose during pregnancy.

questions.text: True regarding pediatric anesthesiology? A. Drug dose and airway size is calculated based upon the child’s weight B. Spinal anesthesia is contraindicated below 6 months of age C. Halothane is not a favoured agent in pediatric anesthesia D. Most preffered mode of induction in a child is inhalational E. Induction agent of choice in a child with tetralogy of fallot is etomidate.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A. Drug dose and airway size is calculated based upon the child’s weight In pediatric anesthesiology, drug dosages are typically calculated on a weight-based (mg/kg) system. Similarly, the size of airway devices like endotracheal tubes is often determined using the child’s weight and age. This ensures both safety and effectiveness when selecting doses and airway equipment. C. Halothane is not a favoured agent in pediatric anesthesia This is true in current practice. Although halothane was historically used in children due to its non-irritant properties and smooth induction, it is no longer favored because of its association with hepatotoxicity, cardiac arrhythmias, and slow recovery. Modern agents like sevoflurane and desflurane are preferred for their safety profiles and faster onset and recovery. D. Most preferred mode of induction in a child is inhalational Inhalational induction is typically the preferred method in pediatric patients, especially younger children who may be uncooperative with intravenous access. Sevoflurane is the most commonly used agent due to its rapid onset, minimal airway irritation, and pleasant odor. Incorrect options: B. Spinal anesthesia is contraindicated below 6 months of age This is incorrect. Spinal anesthesia is not contraindicated below 6 months. In fact, it is considered safe in neonates and young infants for lower abdominal or lower limb surgeries. Though technically challenging, it is used in neonatology and pediatric anesthesia when appropriately indicated. E. Induction agent of choice in a child with tetralogy of Fallot is etomidate This is false. Ketamine is the induction agent of choice in tetralogy of Fallot because it maintains or increases systemic vascular resistance, which helps reduce right-to-left shunting and improves oxygenation. Etomidate lacks this benefit and is not preferred in such cases.

questions.text: Which is best for spontaneous respiration?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) There are 6 types of mapelson circuits • Mapelson A: Magill circuit. This is best for spontaneous ventilation. This is most inefficient circuit for controlled ventilation. • Modification of mapelson A is known as LACK circuit • Mapelson B: obsolete • Mapelson C : known as Waters to and fro circuit. This circuit is used for transportation ans resuscitation. • Mapelson D: Bain circuit. This is best for Controlled ventilation. • Mapelson E: also known as Ayre’s T piece. Used in neonates and spontaneous ventilation in adults. • Modification of mapelson E is known as Jackson reees modification or Mapelson F. it is used for children less than 6 years.

choices.text: Risk of injury to teeth during intubation

questions.text: Modified mallampatti scoring is done to assess-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Modified mallampatti grading is used to assess size of longue for laryngoscopy. This gives us idea about difficulty of intubation. • Mallampatti score grade 3 and 4 are considered to be difficult intubation. • Other tests used for assessment of airway include a. Thyromental distane >6.5cm b. Sternomental distance >12. Cm c. Adequate mouth opening >2cm or 3 fingers breadth

questions.text: Murphy eye is found in-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Murphy eye is a structure present in the lateral wall of PVC beyond the cuff

questions.text: Which of the following nerve is used for monitoring in anesthesia-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • Nerve most commonly used to monitor anesthesia is ulnar nerve and the muscle is adductor pollicis. • Other nerve whu=ich can be used is facial nerve, muscle is orbicularis occuli • Most common method of neuromuscular monitoring is TOF- train of four. Consists of 4 impulses of 2Hz each. Duration between stimulus is 0.5 sec. TOF is repeated every 10 seconds.

questions.text: Anesthetic gas with maximum respiratory irritation
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) -All agents are bronchodilators ( Halothane : Maximum Bronchodilation) - Sevoflurane: Preferred agent for Asthamatics - Desflurane causes maximum respiratory irritation - All inhalational agents are respiratory depressants : Decrease Respiratory rate , decrease oxygen consumption and decrease pulmonary vascular resistance - All agents reduce mucociliary clearance and decrease hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction.

questions.text: IV administration of which anesthetic drug is most painful among the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Effect of IV induction agents on CVS : -Thiopentone : Decrease HR , BP , Prolong QT interval. - Propofol : Decrease HR , BP - Etomidate : Cardio -stable . So used in cardiac surgeries -Ketamine : Increase HR , BP due to sympathetic stimulation. So contraindicated in Hypertension and Past history of MI. Indicated in any hypotensive patient .

questions.text: Which of the following is not cardiodepressive?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common method used to know depth of anesthesia
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Depth of anesthesia is measured by Bispectral index. It is a frontal processed EEG.
